Biographical Note
Edith Linton married Frank Elsworth Hart in Plymouth Church in 1889 or 1890. He died in 1895, leaving her with two small boys. His father, Frederick D. Hart, was chief engineer of Ridgewood Water Works. Edith then became a music teacher in the public schools and retired in 1921. Her son, Ronald Hart, attended Manual Training High School and was a member of the American Expeditionary Forces during World War I. In the 1920s he married Virigina Packard, a librarian, writer, and interior designer. She operated shops out of the Hotel Bossert and on the north shore of Long Island. The Virginia M. Packard Hart Scholarship was established at Pratt Institute in her memory.
Scope and Contents
The Hart family papers include correspondence, certificates, obituary notices, wedding invitations, genealogy notes and papers, deeds, insurance records, securities account books, and items relating to the Manual Training High School. In addition to the Hart family, the papers also document the Linton and Packard families.
The collection contains numerous photographs in a variety of formats, including tintypes (one in a pocket-sized case), ambrotypes (one encased, two on glass), cartes-de-visite, and various types of prints.
Portraits of Hart and Linton family members date from the 1860s through 1966. Also included are photographs of the Packard family, namely Virigina Packard Hart, Reynolds Packard, and his wife Eleanor Packard. Additionally, the papers contain a book of poems written by Reynolds at age 11, along with other memorabilia relating to his life.
Other photographs include images of the interior of the Hart residence at 494 Jamaica Avenue, a portrait of a Civil War solider, a tintype of the opening of the Union Elevated Railroad in 1888, and images Virginia Hart's shop at the Hotel Bossert.
Conditions Governing Access
Open to users without restriction.
Preferred Citation
Identification of item, date (if known); Hart family papers, 1985.050, Box and Folder number; Brooklyn Historical Society.
Processing Information
Minimally processed to the collection level by Marylin Petit, 2006. Finding aid revised and entered into Archivists' Toolkit by Nicholas Pavlik, 2011. Additional photographs discovered and added to the collection, and the finding aid subsequently revised, by John Zarrillo, 2014 and 2015.
Immediate Source of Acquisition
Source and date of acquisition unknown. Formally accessioned in 1985. The papers were probably assembled by Ronald Hart.
